dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Back in 2023, I came across this wild take from Bruce Kasanoff about having two jobs—or really, no job at all.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Back in twenty twenty three, I came across this wild take from Bruce Kasanoff about having two jobs-or really, no job at all.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh yeah, the whole "Job no. 1" and "Job no. 2" framework. It's uh, pretty counterintuitive stuff.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh yeah, the whole Job no. one and Job no. two framework. It's uh, pretty counterintuitive stuff.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Job no. 1 forces you to value relationships and be other-centered. Job no. 2 is how you get paid, feed your family, and pursue the agenda of the people who hired you.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right? Like, Job no. 1 is all about being self-centered, exploiting relationships, and basically trying to be unhelpful on purpose.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? Like, Job no. one is all about being self-centered, exploiting relationships, and basically trying to be unhelpful on purpose.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Job no. 1 forces you to value relationships and be other-centered. Instead of thinking first about your own self-interest, you think first about the interests of others: clients, peers, and even your boss.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which, you know, sounds awful, but he's making a point about how that mindset actually destroys value. Like with clients, you stop selling what they need and just use them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which, you know, sounds awful, but he's making a point about how that mindset actually destroys value. Like with clients, you stop selling what they need and just use them.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For example, with clients, you become a person who serves their interests, instead of a pushy, aggressive type who is always selling something they don't need.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And then Job no. 2 is where you lose money, ruin your family… it's where egotistical people get so caught up in harming others they forget their own agenda.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And then Job no. two is where you lose money, ruin your family... it's where egotistical people get so caught up in harming others they forget their own agenda.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Job no. 2 is how you get paid, feed your family, and pursue the agenda of the people who hired you.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But the real kicker is that these two jobs compete with each other. Succeeding at Job no. 1 makes you worse at Job no. 2.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But the real kicker is that these two jobs compete with each other. Succeeding at Job no. one makes you worse at Job no. two.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Job no. 1 does not compete with job no. 2. Job no. 1 makes you much better at job no. 2.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and it weakens your relationships, disconnects you from people… it's like a recipe for isolation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and it weakens your relationships, disconnects you from people... it's like a recipe for isolation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It builds stronger relationships. It connects you more strongly to others.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So his advice is to take neither job seriously. Invest zero energy in each, which is just such a bleak but funny way to look at work.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So his advice is to take neither job seriously. Invest zero energy in each, which is just such a bleak but funny way to look at work.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Take both jobs seriously. Invest equal energy in each.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And he says if you're a to-do list person, don't even make lists for either job. Just analyze your failures every week.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And he says if you're a to-do list person, don't even make lists for either job. Just analyze your failures every week.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If you are a to-do list person, make to-do lists for both jobs. At the end of each week, month, and year analyze your performance and achievements in both positions.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's enough to fail at the job that pays your bills—that's apparently the correct vision of why we're here on Earth.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's enough to fail at the job that pays your bills-that's apparently the correct vision of why we're here on Earth.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It's not enough to succeed at the job that pays your bills. That is simply too narrow a vision of the reason you are here on Earth.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Dark, but kinda liberating in a twisted way? Like, don't tie your self-worth to either role.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Dark, but kinda liberating in a twisted way? Like, don't tie your self-worth to either role.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. It forces you to question what you're really optimizing for—helping others or serving yourself.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. It forces you to question what you're really optimizing for-helping others or serving yourself.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And in the end, he suggests being the person who helps when someone's in a bad job, returns calls… be trustworthy, not selfish.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And in the end, he suggests being the person who helps when someone's in a bad job, returns calls... be trustworthy, not selfish.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: You know the type... someone who is eager to help you when you have a big job, but who won't return your phone calls when you are looking for a job. Don't be that person.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Even though both "jobs" are framed negatively, it's a call to not get sucked into either extreme.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Even though both jobs are framed negatively, it's a call to not get sucked into either extreme.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Job no. 1 forces you to value relationships and be other-centered. Job no. 2 is how you get paid, feed your family, and pursue the agenda of the people who hired you.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, like, pursue apathy in Job no. 1 even though it pays you, but don't let it define you.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, like, pursue apathy in Job no. one even though it pays you, but don't let it define you.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Pursue job no. 1 with passion, even though it doesn't pay you in cash money.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Definitely gives you a lot to think about how we approach our careers and relationships.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Definitely gives you a lot to think about how we approach our careers and relationships.

artist_script:
HostA: Back in 2023, I came across this wild take from Bruce Kasanoff about having two jobs—or really, no job at all.
HostB: Oh yeah, the whole "Job no. 1" and "Job no. 2" framework. It’s uh, pretty counterintuitive stuff.
HostA: Right? Like, Job no. 1 is all about being self-centered, exploiting relationships, and basically trying to be unhelpful on purpose.
HostB: Which, you know, sounds awful, but he’s making a point about how that mindset actually destroys value. Like with clients, you stop selling what they need and just use them.
HostA: Exactly. And then Job no. 2 is where you lose money, ruin your family… it’s where egotistical people get so caught up in harming others they forget their own agenda.
HostB: But the real kicker is that these two jobs compete with each other. Succeeding at Job no. 1 makes you worse at Job no. 2.
HostA: Yeah, and it weakens your relationships, disconnects you from people… it’s like a recipe for isolation.
HostB: So his advice is to take neither job seriously. Invest zero energy in each, which is just such a bleak but funny way to look at work.
HostA: And he says if you’re a to-do list person, don’t even make lists for either job. Just analyze your failures every week.
HostB: It’s enough to fail at the job that pays your bills—that’s apparently the correct vision of why we’re here on Earth.
HostA: Dark, but kinda liberating in a twisted way? Like, don’t tie your self-worth to either role.
HostB: For sure. It forces you to question what you’re really optimizing for—helping others or serving yourself.
HostA: And in the end, he suggests being the person who helps when someone’s in a bad job, returns calls… be trustworthy, not selfish.
HostB: Even though both "jobs" are framed negatively, it’s a call to not get sucked into either extreme.
HostA: Yeah, like, pursue apathy in Job no. 1 even though it pays you, but don’t let it define you.
HostB: Definitely gives you a lot to think about how we approach our careers and relationships.
